text:
I knew there
were stairs there,

but I thought I'd
try to be tricky.
And oh my goodness.

TANYA HART: Allison,
right over here.

Tanya Hart, American Urban
Radio Networks and online.
Congratulations.
Thank you very much.

TANYA HART: It was
almost like you
were born to play this role.
You, my goodness.
Who knew?

I mean, my friend
Steven certainly

thought I was born to play
it and knew I could play it.

And I didn't think anything
much when I read it.

I didn't think, oh
my god, this is going
to be hard to do until I--

until I started actually
having to do the scenes
and going gosh, I have to--

I have to kind of be
in this woman's skin

and think she's justified
in what she is--

I have to be that woman when
she wakes up in the morning

and thinks she's giving her
daughter the best opportunity

and giving her the
best chance at life,
and I have to believe that.

And then that, that
was my challenge.
And that wasn't--

I wasn't-- having been a figure
skater and watching my parents

get up at 5:00 in the morning
and drive me to the rink

in the morning before school
and after and the commitment it

took from them, I really sort
of felt like I understood that
part of her life with Tonya.

The abuse part was not
easy to understand ever.

But to see how normal
it was in her life,

it was just the way they
reacted with each other.

And you see how
just terrifying it

is to see it treated
in that casual way they

treated each other
with just horrid abuse.

And then the little
secret that I

have about playing this role is
we all have our inner critics,
our inner voices.
We're meanest to ourselves.

And I just sometimes would
imagine me talking to myself

and I'd have scenes with
Margot or with the little girl,

Mckenna Grace, and I'd pretend
I was talking to myself.

And I've been that
mean to myself.
I think we all have.

We all are terrible
to at least-- well,

I'm not going to speak
for everyone here.

But I think we all understand
that is part of our humanity.
Lord.

And that woman had to be a
little girl at some point.

Something went
wrong in her life.

And connecting with
that was my job.
And I like doing that.

I like finding the humanity
in, you know, even this woman.
Thank you.

STEVE FUTTERMAN: Allison,
Steve Futterman from CBS Radio.

I talked to you at the
Golden Globes backstage.
Yes.

STEVE FUTTERMAN: And I
talked to you about how I was
up in Oregon during that time.

I wanted to ask you
though, do you feel Tonya,

and again I'm sure you followed
all the events when they were

taking place contemporaneously
because of your interest

in figure skating--
- Yes, I did.

STEVE FUTTERMAN: Do you feel
she's been misunderstood?

And how would you
like to maybe have

her understood a bit
better now by the world
and the American public?

Well, I think people
seeing the movie

they will have a different
idea of who she is.

They'll have a more nuanced
look at Tonya's life.

All of this movie,
these are her stories
and Jeff Gillooly's stories.
But I feel--
I feel she did get a raw deal.

I think she's been punished
for what she may or may
not have had a direct hand in.
She has been punished.

Taken her whole skating
career away from her.

She had to-- I'm sure she
had to do community service
and was fined.
And I, I just have a greater--

I have empathy for her growing
up with a mother like that

and being faced with all
the adversity she faced

in the figure skating community,
not being embraced for who
she was and not fitting in.
I have real empathy for that.

Especially now, I
think it's why it

resonates right now is because
of those themes and class.
So she was poor.
She was poor and they didn't--

they didn't feel
like she fit in.

She didn't represent the
refined world of figure skating.
And that makes me--

I feel a lot for her,
much more than I did
so when the story first broke.

And I hope other people
will watching the movie.
SCOTT HOOVER: Allison, hi.

Scott Hoover with
Elle back here.
Hi.

In this sort of moment in
time and the conversations

we're having in the culture
about women both in Hollywood

and across the
landscape, have you

found that these conversations
have brought you closer
with your female colleagues?

Have you shared like more
intimate and personal
discussions about these things?
Oh my gosh, yes.
It's been extraordinary.

You know, going to work
everyday at "Mom" with all

these incredible women
I get to act with,

everyone sharing their stories
and talking about this.

I love that everyone
is talking about it.

It is a watershed moment
and everyone is sharing

their stories and
talking about, you know,

everyone's-- it's very
black and white right now.

I think there's a
lot of gray area

and everyone's trying
to define where

we're going with this
movement in terms of--

I mean, there's certain abuses
that are just undeniable.

And others that are
miscommunications and missed--

I was saying on the
press line earlier

how I think there's a
new national safe word,
which is I'm uncomfortable.
I'm uncomfortable.

And that is something
that should transcend
every single industry.
Everyone should know that's a--
I don't know.

That's my thought
for today on that.

But I really am encouraged by
all the conversation that's

going on, because
that's going to affect
change and the conversation.

Going to the Women's
March yesterday

and seeing, hearing
all these, you know,

hearing Viola Davis speak,
hearing Rob Reiner speak.
It was really inspiring.

And I think that we're going
to see a really mobilized--

mobilized population
come the midterms.

And hopefully, more
things will change

and get back to the America
that I thought was great.
Oh, I ramble, I'm sorry, guys.
OK.
[APPLAUSE]
This?
I came with my niece tonight.

She said I was Khaleesi's
warrior shaman.
And I was like, yes.
I love that.
Thank you.
